trans-unit.target: Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: Previous -- Expression Trees Explained
trans-unit.target: Previous -- Expression Trees Explained

trans-unit.source: There is a large list of classes in the .NET Core framework that work with Expression Trees.
trans-unit.target: There is a large list of classes in the .NET Core framework that work with Expression Trees.

trans-unit.source: You can see the full list [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.Expressions).
trans-unit.target: You can see the full list [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/api/System.Linq.Expressions).

trans-unit.source: Rather than run through the full list, let's understand how the framework classes have been designed.
trans-unit.target: Rather than run through the full list, let's understand how the framework classes have been designed.

trans-unit.source: In language design, an expression is a body of code that evaluates and returns a value.
trans-unit.target: In language design, an expression is a body of code that evaluates and returns a value.

trans-unit.source: Expressions may be very simple: the constant expression `1` returns the constant value of 1.
trans-unit.target: Expressions may be very simple: the constant expression `1` returns the constant value of 1.

trans-unit.source: They may be more complicated: The expression `(-B + Math.Sqrt(B*B + 4 * A * C)) / (2 * A)` returns one root for a quadratic equation (in the case where the equation has a solution).
trans-unit.target: They may be more complicated: The expression `(-B + Math.Sqrt(B*B + 4 * A * C)) / (2 * A)` returns one root for a quadratic equation (in the case where the equation has a solution).

trans-unit.source: It all starts with System.Linq.Expression
trans-unit.target: It all starts with System.Linq.Expression

trans-unit.source: One of the complexities of working with expression trees is that many different kinds of expressions are valid in many places in programs.
trans-unit.target: One of the complexities of working with expression trees is that many different kinds of expressions are valid in many places in programs.

trans-unit.source: Consider an assignment expression.
trans-unit.target: Consider an assignment expression.

trans-unit.source: The right hand side of an assignment could be a constant value, a variable, a method call expression, or others.
trans-unit.target: The right hand side of an assignment could be a constant value, a variable, a method call expression, or others.

trans-unit.source: That language flexibility means that you may encounter many different expression types anywhere in the nodes of a tree when you traverse an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: That language flexibility means that you may encounter many different expression types anywhere in the nodes of a tree when you traverse an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, when you can work with the base expression type, that's the simplest way to work.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, when you can work with the base expression type, that's the simplest way to work.

trans-unit.source: However, sometimes you need to know more.
trans-unit.target: However, sometimes you need to know more.

trans-unit.source: The base Expression class contains a `NodeType` property for this purpose.
trans-unit.target: The base Expression class contains a `NodeType` property for this purpose.

trans-unit.source: It returns an `ExpressionType` which is an enumeration of possible expression types.
trans-unit.target: It returns an `ExpressionType` which is an enumeration of possible expression types.

trans-unit.source: Once you know the type of the node, you can cast it to that type, and perform specific actions knowing the type of the expression node.
trans-unit.target: Once you know the type of the node, you can cast it to that type, and perform specific actions knowing the type of the expression node.

trans-unit.source: You can search for certain node types, and then work with the specific properties of that kind of expression.
trans-unit.target: You can search for certain node types, and then work with the specific properties of that kind of expression.

trans-unit.source: For example, this code will print the name of a variable for a variable access expression.
trans-unit.target: For example, this code will print the name of a variable for a variable access expression.

trans-unit.source: I've followed the practice of checking the node type, then casting to a variable access expression and then checking the properties of the specific expression type:
trans-unit.target: I've followed the practice of checking the node type, then casting to a variable access expression and then checking the properties of the specific expression type:

trans-unit.source: Creating Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Creating Expression Trees

trans-unit.source: The `System.Linq.Expression` class also contains many static methods to create expressions.
trans-unit.target: The `System.Linq.Expression` class also contains many static methods to create expressions.

trans-unit.source: These methods create an expression node using the arguments supplied for its children.
trans-unit.target: These methods create an expression node using the arguments supplied for its children.

trans-unit.source: In this way, you build an expression up from its leaf nodes.
trans-unit.target: In this way, you build an expression up from its leaf nodes.

trans-unit.source: For example, this code builds an Add expression:
trans-unit.target: For example, this code builds an Add expression:

trans-unit.source: You can see from this simple example that many types are involved in creating and working with expression trees.
trans-unit.target: You can see from this simple example that many types are involved in creating and working with expression trees.

trans-unit.source: That complexity is necessary to provide the capabilities of the rich vocabulary provided by the C# language.
trans-unit.target: That complexity is necessary to provide the capabilities of the rich vocabulary provided by the C# language.

trans-unit.source: Navigating the APIs
trans-unit.target: Navigating the APIs

trans-unit.source: There are Expression node types that map to almost all of the syntax elements of the C# language.
trans-unit.target: There are Expression node types that map to almost all of the syntax elements of the C# language.

trans-unit.source: Each type has specific methods for that type of language element.
trans-unit.target: Each type has specific methods for that type of language element.

trans-unit.source: It's a lot to keep in your head at one time.
trans-unit.target: It's a lot to keep in your head at one time.

trans-unit.source: Rather than try to memorize everything, here are the techniques I use to work with Expression trees:
trans-unit.target: Rather than try to memorize everything, here are the techniques I use to work with Expression trees:

trans-unit.source: Look at the members of the `ExpressionType` enum to determine possible nodes you should be examining.
trans-unit.target: Look at the members of the `ExpressionType` enum to determine possible nodes you should be examining.

trans-unit.source: This really helps when you want to traverse and understand an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: This really helps when you want to traverse and understand an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: Look at the static members of the `Expression` class to build an expression.
trans-unit.target: Look at the static members of the `Expression` class to build an expression.

trans-unit.source: Those methods can build any expression type from a set of its child nodes.
trans-unit.target: Those methods can build any expression type from a set of its child nodes.

trans-unit.source: Look at the `ExpressionVisitor` class to build a modified expression tree.
trans-unit.target: Look at the `ExpressionVisitor` class to build a modified expression tree.

trans-unit.source: You'll find more as you look at each of those three areas.
trans-unit.target: You'll find more as you look at each of those three areas.

trans-unit.source: Invariably, you will find what you need when you start with one of those three steps.
trans-unit.target: Invariably, you will find what you need when you start with one of those three steps.
